OUR VOLUNTEERS

IN THE

NORTH-WEST.

A READY REFERENCE HANDBOOK.

CAPT. HORACE G. DUNLEVIE,

Late 1st Battalion Governor-General's Foot Guards, Ottawa,

COMPILER.

OTTAWA:
Printed at the Office of the "Daily Free Press," Elgin Street.

1885.
PREFACE.

By kind permission I am allowed the honour of dedicating this little work, "Our Volunteers in the North-West," to the Hon. Mr. A. P. Caron, Minister of Militia of the Dominion, a gentleman whom it may be said—

"He dares do all that may become a man,
Who dares do more, is none."

The object of my labour has been to perpetuate amongst their friends and the public, the names of those brave men who have so nobly answered to the call to arms and placed their lives and services at the disposal of their Queen and country. The work purports to be a list of the officers, non-commissioned officers and men, regiments, troops, batteries, and companies, now on active service in quelling the unhappy disturbances in the North-West territories of the Dominion of Canada. I have taken every precaution to obtain reliable information from headquarters of corps, and humbly trust my efforts will meet with the approval and support of the volunteers and the public generally.

HORACE G. DUNLEVIE,
Late 1st Batt. G. G. Foot Guards,
COMPILER.
"Freund's Music and Drama,"

A REVIEW OF MUSIC AND THE DRAMA,

PUBLISHED AT 88 FIFTH AVENUE, NEW YORK.

SUBSCRIPTION, $4.00 Per Annum.

C. FREUND, Editor. HARRY FREUND, Prop.

OTTAWA, 16TH MAY, 1885.

H. G. D.
ANNUAL
Rifle Matches at Ottawa.

Among the readers of this publication there will be some who will visit the Rifle Ranges in Ottawa in the Fall.
To all such we extend a hearty welcome to our Rooms.
The Reading Room is open from 8.30 a.m., to 10 p.m., being well stocked with Reading matter and papers from the principal cities.

WRITING MATERIALS PROVIDED FREE.
Our well furnished Members' Parlour is also at the disposal of visitors to the City, and would prove a pleasant resort to meet friends by appointment.

During the Summer Iced Water is kept at the Rooms.

Several after visiting our cheerful Rooms have told us that they never knew we had such a pleasant place, as they were prejudiced by what they heard. Do not be influenced in that way, but come and see for yourselves the ways and means used to benefit Young Men.

Our aim is the Spiritual, Mental, Social and Physical Welfare of Young Men.
A hearty welcome will also be accorded Young Men in Associations in other cities.
Our rooms are situated at the S. E. Corner of Sparks and O'Connor Streets.

MEETINGS.

SUNDAY MORNING .......9.45 to 10.45........BIBLE STUDY (INTERNATIONAL LESSON)
SUNDAY AFTERNOON.....3 O'CLOCK........EVANGELISTIC BIBLE CLASS
FRIDAY..................7.30 P. M........MEETING FOR BOYS OVER 12.
SATURDAY...............8 P. M..............YOUNG MEN'S MEETING.
DAILY PRAYER, 4.15 P. M., OPEN TO LADIES.

We earnestly invite you to the above meetings in the hope that you may share the Blessings.

"Being justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ." Rom. v. 1.
"But God commendeth His Love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us." Rom. v., 8.

GUS. A. KUHRING,
GENERAL SECRETARY,
Young Men's Christian Association,
OTTAWA.
DR. AUSTIN'S

PHOSPHATINE

CURES ALL NERVOUS DISEASES.

If you are a professional man, so thoroughly overworked that every mental effort is attended with a sense of weariness followed by headache and more or less severe nervous prostration—take Phosphatine every day for a week or more.

If you find that you are unable to sleep nights, and though physically tired are wakeful, and your business is uppermost in your mind, and you cannot for awhile rid yourself of its cares and perplexities—take Phosphatine in the same way for a month or more.

What the Rev. A. T. Green, of Port Hope, has to say.

PORT HOPE, October 31st, 1883.

Gentlemen,—For a long time my stomach and liver have troubled me very much, and for eighteen months I have had chronic inflammation of the liver, during which time I constantly grew worse until I was confined to my bed for weeks, having chills and fever three or four times each day, my skin was yellow. My stomach ceased to act, and I wasted away to a mere skeleton. Medical men were unable to help me. Patent medicines did me no good. On the 26th of July, when my friends as well as myself had given up hope, I was persuaded to try one of your Pads. In three days it cured the chills and fever, and made me feel much better. This improvement continued until I felt quite well in every way except my stomach, which, though mending and better than it has been for years, is not entirely cured. From my experience, and what I have heard of your Pads, I strongly recommend them to all suffering from troubles of the stomach, liver, or bowels.

REV. A. T. GREEN, Methodist Minister.
